wiki_catalogs.name: Project Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the project overview focused on the VoxWeave text-to-speech and AI video generation platform. Explain its purpose as a full-stack Rust application enabling conversion of text to narrated videos with AI visuals and subtitles. Document the dual nature of the system with both CLI and multi-platform Dioxus UI (desktop, web, mobile). Describe the core architecture with modular design, feature flags, and async processing pipeline. Highlight key features including multi-engine TTS (espeak-ng, Kokoro, CoquiTTS), voice cloning, Z.AI video generation, and cyberpunk-themed UI. Include practical examples of common workflows like converting a markdown file to a narrated video. Explain relationships between components: how CLI and UI both depend on the shared core library, and how services integrate through feature flags. Address beginner concepts like environment variables for API keys and Rust feature flags, while providing technical depth on the async tokio runtime and service-oriented design. Use terminology consistent with the codebase such as 'pipeline', 'voice profiles', and 'queue processing'.

wiki_catalogs.name: Prerequisites
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the prerequisites required to install and run VoxWeave. Detail the necessary software versions: Rust 1.80+ (with Cargo), Python 3.8+ with pip, and system-level dependencies such as espeak-ng and FFmpeg. Explain the role of each dependency in the systemRust for core and UI compilation, Python for CoquiTTS bridge and voice cloning, and system tools for audio/video processing. Include instructions for installing these on major platforms (Linux, macOS, Windows via WSL if applicable). Reference abogen-ui/README.md for Dioxus-specific UI requirements and COQUI_USAGE_GUIDE.md for Python package needs (TTS, torch, numpy). Highlight GPU acceleration prerequisites (CUDA, cuDNN) when using CoquiTTS with GPU support. Provide verification commands (e.g., rustc --version, python --version, espeak-ng --version) to confirm installations. Address common pitfalls like Python virtual environment misconfigurations and missing build tools.

wiki_catalogs.name: Core Functionality
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the core functionality of VoxWeave focused on the text-to-speech and AI video generation pipeline. Explain its purpose as a modular Rust library that processes text input into audio, subtitles, and optionally AI-generated videos. Document the implementation details of the pipeline orchestration in src/pipeline.rs, including text normalization, chunking, TTS synthesis, and SRT generation. Highlight the multi-engine TTS architecture with support for espeak-ng, Kokoro, and CoquiTTS, detailing how each engine implements the TtsEngine trait. Describe the video generation process via Z.AI API integration in src/video.rs, including prompt construction and style selection. Include practical examples from the codebase such as using the PipelineBuilder pattern, handling voice profiles, and managing output directories. Explain integration points between components: how TTS engines feed audio data into video generation, and how configuration flows from CLI/UI to service layers. Address common issues like missing dependencies, API rate limits, and audio-video synchronization problems. Provide performance considerations for batch processing and async execution using tokio.

wiki_catalogs.name: Rust Dependencies
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the Rust dependencies focused on the VoxWeave core and UI crates. Detail the primary dependencies: Dioxus 0.7 for cross-platform UI development across desktop, web, and mobile; clap 4 for CLI argument parsing with derive macros; tokio 1 for async runtime with features enabling filesystem access, process spawning, and HTTP requests; reqwest 0.11 for API communication with Z.AI video generation service; serde 1 with derive features for serialization of configuration and API payloads; and anyhow/thiserror for robust error handling. Explain how optional features like 'video-generation' activate tokio and reqwest, enabling conditional compilation. Include code snippets from Cargo.toml files showing workspace configuration, feature flag usage, and dependency scoping. Document the role of each crate in the architecture, integration patterns between components, and performance implications of async usage. Address version compatibility across the workspace and best practices for dependency updates.

wiki_catalogs.name: Convert Command
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the 'convert' subcommand in the voxweave CLI. Explain its role in converting text/markdown files to audio with optional subtitles, as implemented in src/main.rs using clap. Document all available options such as --voice, --speed, --output, --subtitles, --words, --replace-single-newlines, --keep-single-newlines, and --wpm. Provide practical examples showing common usage patterns like basic audio generation, subtitle configuration, and speed adjustments. Detail how the command integrates with the core pipeline in src/pipeline.rs to clean text, generate audio via the selected TTS engine, and produce SRT subtitle files. Include error handling scenarios and configuration persistence (updating default voice and recent files). Make content accessible to beginners with simple examples while providing technical depth on the conversion workflow for advanced users.

wiki_catalogs.name: Interface Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the UI application interface overview focused on the Dioxus-based cross-platform design. Explain the cyberpunk-themed visual identity with neon accents (cyan, magenta, amber, lime) and dark backgrounds as defined in theme.rs, including CSS variables like --bg, --neon-cyan, and --panel-bg. Describe the two primary screens: Main Screen for file selection and configuration, and Processing Screen for real-time feedback. Document the use of Rajdhani font from Google Fonts and responsive layout principles that adapt to desktop, web, and mobile platforms. Include guidance on how the theme is applied globally via get_theme_css() and integrated into the root App component. Provide examples from abogen-ui/README.md showing expected user flow and visual hierarchy. Address accessibility features such as focus states, keyboard navigation, and color contrast compliance (WCAG AA). Explain how feature flags like 'real-tts' and 'video-generation' affect UI visibility and behavior.

wiki_catalogs.name: Espeak Engine Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Espeak TTS engine integration. Explain how the EspeakEngine struct implements the SpeechEngine trait using system command execution via std::process::Command. Document the voice selection mechanism that maps VoiceProfile.command to espeak voice identifiers, and the speed normalization logic that converts float speed multipliers to espeak's rate parameter (80-450 WPM). Detail the text streaming approach using stdin piping to handle large inputs efficiently. Include configuration options such as the VOXWEAVE_ESPEAK_COMMAND environment variable for custom espeak binary paths. Provide examples from the code showing how empty text input is handled by writing empty audio files. Address performance considerations like subprocess startup overhead and lack of GPU acceleration. Include troubleshooting guidance for common issues such as missing espeak installations, voice not found errors, and encoding problems with special characters.

wiki_catalogs.name: Queue Processing
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for queue processing focused on the job management system in src/queue.rs and its integration with the UI state management. Explain the Queue struct design and its role in managing multiple conversion jobs with prioritization, status tracking, and error handling. Document the interaction between the UI's AppState and the queue system, showing how queued items are processed sequentially with real-time progress updates. Detail the implementation of the QueueModal component that provides visual queue management with add, remove, and clear operations. Include examples from tts_service.rs demonstrating how the process_queue function handles cancellation, logging, and progress reporting during batch processing. Address common issues such as handling missing source files, processing interruptions, and error recovery. Provide performance considerations for managing large queues and memory usage optimization.

wiki_catalogs.name: Video Styles
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the video styles feature in the VoxWeave application. Explain the implementation of supported styles including cyberpunk, cinematic, educational, realistic, anime, 3d, and biotech as defined in the VideoGenerationService. Document how style selection affects the visual output and API requests to Z.AI and OpenAI Sora. Include examples of style-specific prompts and their impact on generated content. Describe the mapping between style enum values and API parameters in the create_video_job method. Address common issues such as invalid style selection and API compatibility. Provide guidance on choosing appropriate styles for different content types (e.g., educational content vs. creative storytelling).

wiki_catalogs.name: Building the CLI Application
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for building the VoxWeave CLI application from source. Provide step-by-step instructions for compiling the project using Cargo, including debug and release builds. wiki_catalogs.name: Code Structure

Describe the UI architecture in abogen-ui/crates/ui/, emphasizing component modularity, state management through state.rs, and service layer separation. Illustrate data flow from CLI/UI input through the pipeline to output generation. Include diagrams showing component relationships and call flows for text-to-speech and video generation workflows. Provide examples of extending the codebase, such as adding a new TTS engine or integrating an additional video API. Address cross-platform considerations in the UI build system using Dioxus and Trunk for web, tauri for desktop, and dioxus-mobile for mobile targets.

Document the modular organization of core components: pipeline.rs for processing orchestration, tts.rs for speech synthesis abstraction, video.rs for AI video generation via Z.AI API, and config.rs for configuration management. Explain the trait-based design that enables multiple TTS engines (espeak-ng, Kokoro, CoquiTTS) to be integrated through a common interface. Illustrate the data flow from text input through audio generation, subtitle creation, and video synthesis. Include details on error handling, async processing with tokio, and how feature flags conditionally compile video generation capabilities. Provide code examples showing how external components consume the core library API.

wiki_catalogs.name: Z.AI Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Z.AI video generation integration in VoxWeave. Thoroughly explain the implementation in `zai_video.rs`, focusing on the `ZaiVideoService` struct and its `generate_video` method that orchestrates video creation via the Z.AI API. Document the `ZaiVideoRequest` and `ZaiVideoStatusResponse` data models, including fields like `style`, `resolution`, and optional `prompt`. Include concrete examples from the codebase such as the style-to-prompt mapping for cyberpunk and biotech themes, and the composition pipeline that combines Z.AI-generated video with local audio and subtitles using MLT. Explain the polling mechanism in `poll_video_status` with its 10-minute timeout and 5-second intervals, and how progress is mapped from 30% to 80% during processing. Detail the integration with the UI layer through `Signal` types for real-time log and progress updates. Address common issues like API authentication failures, job timeouts, and subtitle synchronization challenges. Provide configuration guidance for the `ZAI_API_KEY` environment variable and performance considerations for network bandwidth during video download.

wiki_catalogs.name: Core Services
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the core services in the VoxWeave platform. Describe the service-oriented design of the pipeline module, focusing on the ConvertRequest struct and its role in orchestrating text-to-speech and subtitle generation workflows. Document the interaction between the pipeline functions (convert_path, convert_queue) and the underlying TTS engines through the SpeechEngine trait abstraction. Explain how the core services handle text cleaning, audio synthesis, and SRT subtitle generation with proper error propagation using anyhow. Illustrate the data flow from input text through cleaned output to final audio and subtitle files, including file system operations and path sanitization. Detail the integration points between the CLI interface and these core services, highlighting the shared functionality used by both CLI and UI entry points. Include examples from pipeline.rs demonstrating queue processing and error handling patterns. Address performance considerations such as batch processing efficiency and memory usage during file operations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Pipeline Orchestration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the pipeline orchestration system focused on src/pipeline.rs. Explain how the convert_path function coordinates the end-to-end transformation from raw text to audio and subtitle files. Describe the sequence: reading input text, cleaning with src/text.rs, sanitizing filenames via src/sanitize.rs, synthesizing speech through a TTS engine, and generating timed subtitles using src/subtitle.rs. Detail the ConvertRequest structure that encapsulates all conversion parameters including voice, speed, and subtitle timing options. Illustrate how convert_queue enables batch processing by dequeuing items and applying convert_path to each. Provide a step-by-step walkthrough of the pipeline execution with example inputs and outputs. Include error handling for file I/O, text processing, and synthesis failures. Show how average_words_per_minute affects subtitle timing. Demonstrate customization points such as newline replacement and granular subtitle control.

wiki_catalogs.name: Audio & Subtitle Pipeline
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the audio and subtitle generation pipeline in the VoxWeave platform. Describe the coordinated process of TTS synthesis and subtitle creation, starting from the ConvertRequest in the pipeline module. Document the SpeechEngine trait implementation across different engines (espeak, Kokoro, CoquiTTS), focusing on how they handle text-to-speech conversion with voice profiles and speed adjustments. Explain the subtitle generation process, including sentence vs. word-level granularity, timing calculation based on words-per-minute, and SRT formatting. Detail how the pipeline integrates these components: cleaned text is sent to the TTS engine to generate audio, while simultaneously being processed for subtitles with synchronized timing. Include the role of VoiceProfile in engine selection and configuration, and how CoquiTTS enables voice cloning through speaker_wav references. Address error handling in TTS execution and subtitle edge cases like empty text.

wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the UI component library focused on reusable Dioxus components in the components/ directory. Describe the cyberpunk styling implemented through CSS classes and theme.rs integration. Address accessibility considerations, responsive behavior, and animation patterns. wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# VoxWeave Project Analysis

## 1. Project Introduction

VoxWeave is a Rust-first text-to-speech pipeline with a focus on test-driven development. The project converts plain text or markdown files into audio using multiple speech synthesis engines, with optional timed SRT subtitle generation. It supports various TTS engines including espeak-ng, Kokoro, and CoquiTTS with voice cloning capabilities.

The core goals of VoxWeave are to provide a reliable, extensible text-to-speech solution with multiple engine backends, support for voice cloning, and optional AI video generation from text content. The target audience includes developers, content creators, and researchers who need programmatic text-to-speech conversion with advanced features like voice cloning and video generation.

## 2. Technical Architecture

The VoxWeave architecture consists of a CLI application with multiple backends and a multi-platform UI built with Dioxus. The system follows a modular design with clear separation between core functionality, UI components, and service integrations.

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[CLI Interface] --> B[TTS Engines]
    A --> C[Video Generation]
    B --> D[Espeak-ng]
    B --> E[Kokoro]
    B --> F[CoquiTTS]
    C --> G[Z.AI API]
    C --> H[OpenAI Sora]
    I[UI Application] --> J[Core Services]
    J --> B
    J --> C
    K[Configuration] --> A
    K --> I
```

The architecture follows a layered approach with the CLI and UI as frontends, TTS engines as the core processing layer, and external APIs as integration points. The system uses environment variables for configuration and supports feature flags to enable optional functionality.

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- [main.rs](src/main.rs)
- [abogen-ui/apps/web/src/main.rs](abogen-ui/apps/web/src/main.rs)
- [abogen-ui/apps/desktop/src/main.rs](abogen-ui/apps/desktop/src/main.rs)

### Core Modules
- [pipeline.rs](src/pipeline.rs)
- [tts.rs](src/tts.rs)
- [coqui_tts.rs](src/coqui_tts.rs)
- [video.rs](src/video.rs)

### Configuration Approach
- [Cargo.toml](Cargo.toml)
- [abogen-ui/Cargo.toml](abogen-ui/Cargo.toml)
- Environment variables with VOXWEAVE_* prefix

### External Dependencies
- [Cargo.toml](Cargo.toml)
- [kokoro_bridge.py](python/kokoro_bridge.py)

### Integration Points
- [video.rs](src/video.rs)
- [tts.rs](src/tts.rs)
- [services/tts_service.rs](abogen-ui/crates/ui/services/tts_service.rs)

```mermaid
graph LR
    A[CLI] --> B[Pipeline]
    C[UI] --> B
    B --> D[TTS Engines]
    B --> E[Subtitle Generation]
    D --> F[Espeak-ng]
    D --> G[Kokoro]
    D --> H[CoquiTTS]
    B --> I[Video Generation]
    I --> J[Z.AI API]
    I --> K[OpenAI Sora]
```

## 4. Key Features

VoxWeave provides several key features for text-to-speech conversion and media generation:

1. **Multi-engine TTS Support**: Integration with espeak-ng, Kokoro, and CoquiTTS engines
2. **Voice Cloning**: CoquiTTS integration with voice cloning from reference audio
3. **AI Video Generation**: Creation of narrated videos with AI-generated visuals
4. **Multi-platform UI**: Desktop, mobile, and web interfaces built with Dioxus
5. **Subtitle Generation**: Automatic creation of timed subtitles in multiple formats

```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> Idle
    Idle --> TextProcessing: convert request
    TextProcessing --> AudioGeneration: clean text
    AudioGeneration --> SubtitleGeneration: generate audio
    SubtitleGeneration --> VideoGeneration: create subtitles
    VideoGeneration --> Complete: generate video
    Complete --> Idle: finish
    AudioGeneration --> Complete: without video
```

The implementation highlights include the modular TTS engine interface, the video generation service with multiple provider support, and the Dioxus-based UI with state management for complex workflows.
</blog>
